title: Sunderland sack manager Jack Ross... leaving them without a boss just FIVE HOURS before a game
text:
Sunderland have sacked manager Jack Ross just five hours before their game against Grimsby.

The Black Cats sit in sixth place in League One, four points behind second-placed Wycombe Wanderers - who they face after the international break.

Ross' side failed to keep a single clean sheet in the league.

SAFC chairman Stewart Donald said: 'This is a decision that has been made with a heavy heart. When we arrived at the club 18 months ago, we appointed Jack because we felt that he was the right man to take Sunderland forward over a number of years.

Sunderland have sacked manager Jack Ross just five hours before their game against Grimsby

A 2-0 loss away to Lincoln City on Saturday proved to be the final nail in the coffin for the Scot

'Jack has worked extremely hard, and has helped us achieve stability at the club, and I sincerely thank him for his efforts. I hope and believe that he will go on to have a successful career in management.'

Assistant manager James Fowler has been placed in temporary charge of first team affairs and will oversee the Grimsby Town Football League Trophy game at the Stadium of Light.

The process to appoint a new Sunderland manager will commence tomorrow, according to an official statement released by the club.

Tyler Walker of Lincoln celebrates scoring the first of a brace against Ross' Sunderland side

Ross managed to guide Sunderland to the EFL Trophy and League One play-off final last season, losing to Portsmouth and Charlton respectively.

But results have been patchy this season and a 2-0 loss away to Lincoln City on Saturday proved to be the final nail in the coffin for the Scot.

The 2017/18 PFA Scottish Manager of the Year had hoped to lead a revival at the Stadium of Light after Sunderland's free fall from the Premier League.

He was reportedly linked to Ipswich Town but opted for the Black Cats in the wake of their second successive relegation.

The former Alloa Athletic and St Mirren manager has enjoyed strong League Cup form this season.

Under him, Sunderland saw off Premier League competition in Burnley during their second round clash.

Sunderland put three past the Clarets with only one in response, the same as they did against Accrington Stanley in the first round.

In the third round late last month they claimed another impressive scalp, beating Sheffield United 0-1 away from home.

But inconsistent recent form wasn't enough to keep chairman Stewart Donald from cutting ties with the 43-year-old who is now without a club.
